title-group.article-title: Shaping and Cutting the Media Agenda
title-group.subtitle: Television Reporters’ Perceptions of Agenda- and Frame-Building and Agenda-Cutting Influences

abstract.p: This monograph examines television reporters’ perceptions of how sources both within and outside the media attempt to influence news content and coverage decisions and to what degree they are successful. Using structural equation modeling and original data from a national web survey of television reporters, this research explores how market size, extramedia, organizational, and within-media forces influence television news content from a comprehensive perspective. The study also attempts to advance theory with the development and expansion of agenda cutting, and by updating the literature for agenda building and frame building as well as the social control of the newsroom.

body.p: Americans spend more time using media than any other waking activity.1 Data from the U.S. Census Bureau’s Statistical Abstract indicate that, in 2012, Americans are expected to spend almost 1,600 hours watching television, which averages to more than four hours a day.2 Television is also the most popular medium for obtaining the news of the day. A Pew Research Center Poll released in 2010 revealed that an average of 76 percent of adults reported watching local or broadcast news “sometimes” or “regularly.” The figure for cable news was only slightly lower with 70 percent, while network news acquired less interest with 55 percent.3

With audiences devoting so much of their attention to television news, it is important to examine what is being aired on these broadcasts. Perhaps more significant, however, is how these news topics and stories came to be chosen, or not chosen, in the first place. What forces, both internal and external, were involved in the news-decision process? Did owners or top-level executives suggest a particular story to cover or emphasize? Did newsroom management influence a reporter’s decision of if and how he or she would cover that event? Or did advertisers exert pressure on the news organization to avoid covering a particular story because the coverage could be harmful to its company’s image or profits? All are important questions that should be asked regarding news coverage.

Ample evidence of attempts and successes of influencing the media abound, especially in the area of advertising. For instance, Camel cigarettes sponsored the “Camel News Caravan” on NBC in the 1950s (Weblink 1).4 As a part of the agreement, NBC was not permitted to film any newscasts with shots of cigars or where a “No Smoking” sign was visible.5 According to former NBC News President Reuven Frank in his book Out of Thin Air, “What Camel wanted Camel got.”6 Decades later, Mother Jones, a liberal magazine, published articles that linked cigarette smoking and cancer, although the staff thought it might lead to repercussions from their tobacco advertisers. Their concerns were well founded, as the companies pulled their ads from the magazine.7 Ms. magazine suffered similar consequences from Clairol after publishing a report on congressional hearings concerning hair dyes and their chemicals being absorbed through the skin, which may be carcinogenic. The company eventually changed its formulas but also pulled ads from the publication as a result of the reports.8

Other anecdotal evidence illuminates possible cases of ownership influence as well. NBC’s Saturday Night Live ran a cartoon skit that criticized media ownership concentration and its effects on news content—including stories about General Electric (GE), the network’s parent company (Weblink 2). When NBC reran the episode months later, the cartoon segment was cut, reportedly because it lacked comedic value.9 According to an editorial in The Nation, however, a source from the network reported that both NBC’s president and GE executives were displeased with the material.10 Those writing and producing entertainment pieces may not be the only group under pressure from owners and top executives, as news workers may be feeling the heat as well. A 2000 survey conducted by Pew Research Center and Columbia Journalism Review (CJR) found that 51 percent of local journalists felt that corporate owners influence news organizations’ decisions about which stories to cover or emphasize “a great deal” or “a fair amount.”11

While many empirical studies have centered on how media content may affect audiences, fewer have taken a step back to consider who or what is influencing the media’s decisions. Some researchers have pointed out that more knowledge is needed on how and by whom the media agenda is set.12 Others have called for more evidence to increase our understanding of how and through what forces media frames are constructed.13 Furthermore, few researchers have delved into the area of how and why certain news items are simply kept off, or cut out of, the media agenda.

Thus, the purpose of this monograph is to examine through what forces and under what conditions the media are most likely to be influenced and to what effect on news content. That is, how and under what conditions do external and internal forces attempt to influence the media and their coverage, and to what effect are they successful at doing so?

Specifically, this research measures the potential outcomes of attempts at influencing coverage decisions and news content. Using aspects from Shoemaker and Reese’s hierarchical model of influences,14 along with research and examples from agenda-building and framing literature, a comprehensive model of media influences and outcomes is tested using a survey of TV reporters and structural equation modeling (see Figure 1 for the basic theoretical model).

caption.p: Theoretical model of Influences on Media Content (IOMC)

body.p: This study’s overall goal is to examine extramedia, organizational, and within-media forces that may influence news media content. As indicated in the Influences on Media Content (IOMC) model, this monograph proposes that extramedia (e.g., advertiser, public relations, and political pressures) and organizational (e.g., economic, owner/executive, and staff size pressures) influences on content decision effects/outcomes are mediated through within-media organization influences, such as direct and indirect management pressures. Specifically, the study evaluated extramedia and organizational influences with (1) each other, as indicated by the double-headed arrows; (2) within-media influences; and (3) influences/effects on content, such as levels of agenda building, frame building, and agenda cutting, as mediated through within-media influences.

sec.title: Literature Review
sec.p: Shoemaker and Reese have pointed out that media content can be influenced on various levels. Researchers before them investigated the notion of gatekeeping and, within the realm of media studies, noted that gatekeepers exist at each level, allowing certain news items to pass through to the next stage toward broadcast or publication while others are filtered out of consideration.15 With these studies of gatekeeping and the “control” of news flow in mind, Shoemaker and Reese developed the hierarchical model of influences. They argue that media choice of the presentation of news items operate on different levels, ranging from macro to micro, to influence the content that is eventually received by the audience. The levels of influence are ideological, extramedia, organizational, media routines, and individual.16 The current monograph and proposed model draw from particular levels of Shoemaker and Reese’s study, along with aspects from agenda building, framing, and agenda cutting. Only those influence levels and potential effects on content assessed in the current study are addressed in the review of literature that follows in order to provide justification for the specific goals of this project. The pressure sources included in this study are extramedia, organizational, and within-media influences. Although the “within-media” stage of influence is not explicitly outlined in Shoemaker and Reese’s hierarchical model, this construct draws upon ideas from the “media routines” level but offers more personalized newsroom information. The potential influences/outcomes on content are levels of agenda building, frame building, and agenda cutting. The following sections explain each of the influence levels and the possible effects on news media content.

sec.title: Extramedia Influences
sec.p: Potential extramedia levels of influence include advertisers, public relations efforts, government and political, and interest groups. Studies have relied on this level of analysis in an attempt to get to the first step in the gatekeeping and agenda-building processes.17 Berkowitz argued that the relationship between journalists and news sources should be examined in addition to the practice of newsgathering when considering the agenda-building process.18 The term “sources” not only refers to individuals associated with an event or issue, but may also include organization-based information. Gandy referred to these latter sources as “information subsidies” and stressed their importance in the agenda-building process.19 To further examine extramedia influences, three specific sources of pressure are considered: advertiser, public relations, and political/government.

sec.title: Advertiser Pressures
sec.p: A number of examples concerning advertiser influences on the media have emerged over the years. A 1992 study found that more than 89 percent of the 150 newspaper editors surveyed said “advertisers had pulled ads or tried to influence stories,” with most of the pressure appearing to come from automobile dealers.20 One year before, an American Journalism Review (AJR) article reported that angry auto dealers pulled television ads after the station aired stories concerning dangerous vehicles, an unhappy customer, and tips on saving money when buying a new car.21

Advertisers may sometimes assume that they have special access to the news22 or may lay out guidelines of what type of content that is to be run (or not run) in the same issue/segment of their advertisements23 because they know the media are dependent upon them for revenues. Several examples have surfaced in the magazine industry. Gloria Steinem, editor of Ms. magazine, has said that Proctor & Gamble, for example, insisted that its products’ advertisements should not run in “any issue that included any material on gun control, abortion, the occult, cults, or the disparagement of religion. Caution was also demanded in any issue covering sex or drugs, even for educational purposes.”24 The Chrysler Corporation, according to Croteau and Hoynes, required magazines to provide a summary of the topics and articles of upcoming issues, and the company was to be notified in advance if an issue might cover any topics that could be taken as offensive.25

Media critics, such as Ben Bagdikian and Robert McChesney, argue that audiences are gathered not to be informed, but to be sold to advertisers. Therefore, Bagdikian contends, a few large corporations win while the public loses.26 Baker also noted that news managers are faced with trying to satisfy several publics, including viewers, stockholders, and advertisers.27 He contends that ultimately the favor typically goes to the public that (1) is the larger purchaser, (2) with the most knowledge as to how the media can serve its needs, and (3) the most sensitive to how the media can affects its interests. In other words, the influence tends to go to the advertiser—not the audience. As Altschull put it, “The press is the piper, and the tune the piper plays is composed by those who pay the piper.”28

According to Croteau and Hoynes, advertisers have “substantial influence over what is and is not emphasized in the media,” but traditionally, this influence is “fairly subtle and indirect.”29 The authors give examples of how the media alert entities, such as airlines and oil companies, if the news content could potentially present them in an unfavorable light. For instance, if there is an oil-spill story or an airplane crash, the companies may be offered the chance to reschedule ads.30 Pressure from advertisers may also be more direct, especially in recent years.

Research in the newspaper and magazine industries has also found evidence of advertiser influences.31 For example, Hays and Reisner’s study of farm magazine writers found that 62 percent of those surveyed reported “receiving threats to withdraw advertising from advertisers displeased by editorial copy,” while 48 percent said that advertisers had actually withdrawn advertising from their publications.32 Moreover, 65 percent claimed to have received phone calls from advertising and public relations representatives “pushing products or copy” and reported that they deemed such pressures as effective.33 Although the study is limited because it deals with niche publications from a controlled sample of American Agricultural Editors Association (AAEA) members, it still has merit because studies involving more generalist media have produced similar findings.34

According to Shoemaker and Reese, broadcast media are more vulnerable to advertiser pressures than print media because they are more sensitive to profit needs and rely on advertising sources for revenue.35 A study by the Project for Excellence in Journalism surveyed local television news directors and found that more than 30 percent reported “being pressured to kill negative stories or do positive ones about advertisers.”36 Similarly, Just, Levine, and Regan found that 53 percent of the 118 local news directors surveyed alleged the exact same types of pressures and noted that their findings raise a red flag concerning journalistic autonomy in this medium.37 This figure reflects an increase from a smaller-scale survey the authors conducted just a year earlier, suggesting the problem may be getting worse. Tuchman made a similar point in 1978 when she asserted that news workers in the television industry occasionally link advertiser preferences to their own news judgments based on organizational directives.38

Furthermore, a 1999 Pew survey found that more than 30 percent of the staff in local media was concerned with advertiser pressures a “great deal” or a “fair amount.”39 A 2000 survey, however, showed an increase in concerns about advertisers, as 43 percent of local journalists thought that advertising concerns influenced news organizations’ decisions about what stories to cover or emphasize “a great deal” or “a fair amount.”40 A 2007 Pew survey found a further increase, with 46 percent of responding journalists claiming advertiser pressures.41

sec.title: Public Relations Pressures
sec.p: Another potential source of outside influence on the media is public relations pressures. One of the main goals of public relations practitioners is to create and maintain a positive image in the eyes of the public over time. To accomplish this goal, those in the field use the media to communicate their messages to the masses. If they are successful in getting their messages placed in the media, “they influence the media agenda, which can in turn influence public opinion and the public agenda.”42 This process of influencing media choices is known as agenda building. The messages take the form of information subsidies and consist of communication pieces such as press releases, public service announcements (PSAs), broadcast news releases (BNRs), video news releases (VNRs), press conferences, and official proceedings, to name a few.43 Practitioners provide information subsidies to the media in an attempt to garner media coverage on behalf of their clients in order to reach their target audiences.44

Information subsidies from public relations practitioners are provided at no cost to the media. Typical news stories produced by news organizations involve expenses, including equipment costs and worker salaries. Thus, media entities facing budget cuts and bottom-line pressures, or simply those with a small number of staff, may be more willing to use these subsidies to fill their news holes at a low cost.45 Regardless, news organizations tend to use information subsidies, even if solely for generating story ideas.

Many studies have focused on public relations influences and information subsidy use in print media,46 but further evidence suggests that it may be even more prevalent in the television industry because of more severe economic constraints.47 In their 1989 study comparing decisions on news releases by television and newspaper gatekeepers, Abbott and Brassfield found that small television stations were more likely to use releases, with a 59 percent acceptance rate, while both small and large newspapers rejected the most (33.5 and 24 percent, respectively).48 This finding was somewhat surprising since, according to the authors, previous research indicated that newspaper gatekeepers were more likely to accept releases because of larger news holes. A year later, Berkowitz and Adams’s study involving one station found that fewer than 25 percent of the information subsidies were retained. Those that were used at this local station were mainly from nonprofit organizations and interest groups, despite the higher numbers received from government and business sources.49

Although studies indicate that subsidies are indeed accepted, albeit at different rates, the literature suggests a strained relationship between public relations practitioners and journalists that may lead some news workers to exhibit reluctance at using pieces provided by these sources.50 This relationship may be due to journalists’ suspicions of public relations professionals’ practices, as they may view them as simply trying to promote their own agendas by only presenting their client in a positive light while withholding other pertinent information. Strained journalist-practitioner relationships may be attributed, in part, to the controversial use and misuse of VNRs by media organizations. VNRs are typically created and provided by public relations firms, government or corporate agencies, or interest groups with the hopes of garnering media coverage and, thus, influencing the audience. In some instances, stations run them without revealing that the video segments are produced by outside sponsors, agencies, or corporations, which is against the ethical guidelines set forth by the Radio Television Digital News Association (RTDNA).51 Thus, the public may not be able to distinguish between a VNR and a “real” news story put together by a station’s news team. Literature shows that broadcast public relations firms and other sources have been successful at getting their pieces run in the media. In fact, Farsetta and Price found that 77 stations under study aired the VNRs “as is” more than 30 percent of the time, and in 100 percent of the cases, the stations made the pieces appear like it was their own reporting.52 Thus, the organizations that provided the information, and the clients that they represent, were reasonably successful in influencing the media’s news agenda.

sec.title: Political/Government Pressures
sec.p: Besides public relations and advertising pressures, political influences on the media may also exist. In addition to the more blatant influence tactics such as campaign advertising, governmental communications specialists may also attempt to influence media content through information sources that Berkowitz has called “informal” channels:53 news leaks, off-the-record interviews, and backgrounders.54 This somewhat hidden type of pressure may help explain the dearth of academic literature covering instances of politicians and government officials attempting to influence news coverage.

Like the public relations materials previously discussed, these sources are considered information subsidies. According to Shoemaker and Reese, these channels “can be used very effectively to set the agenda for the news media—something that U.S. presidents do not fail to attempt.”55 For example, Ponder’s study of the first presidential press corps found that President William McKinley achieved favorable press coverage by holding press briefings on a regular basis and by providing reporters with advanced copies of his statements and speeches, thus making their work easier by subsidizing the information.56 Therefore, the president and the White House were able to build the media’s news agenda by simplifying the newsgathering process. Furthermore, they were more able to “easily win the framing contest”57 by making certain that the subsidies provided contained the main messages and frames that they wanted relayed to the public while leaving out and drawing attention away from those that they did not want brought to light.58 According to Pan and Kosicki, “framing an issue is more a strategic means to attract more supporters, to mobilize collections, to expand actors’ realm of influences, and to increase their chances of winning.”59 This “winning” can be thought of as obtaining a desired amount, type, and frame of media coverage or winning either public support or support from others in government. Berkowitz provided further backing for McKinley’s type of strategy. He found that 71 percent of network and 75 percent of local news stories relied upon “routine news channels” such as press conferences, official proceedings, and press releases.60 Moreover, television news used these types of channels more often than newspapers. Additional literature suggests that other levels of government are also successful at influencing media coverage, namely because journalists tend to rely on official sources and official government opinion for their news stories.61

Although it may seem that the media actively seek out official government views, as indicated in the previous cases, the government and politicians seek to influence the press coverage as well. Gandy noted that “at every level of government, in every agency, there are information specialists whose responsibility it is to ensure that the nation’s public media carry the desired message forward.”62 In many cases, those working for politicians and government officials use prepackaged news such as VNRs and print releases, the same communication tools used by public relations practitioners. In fact, political figures and the specialized departments in government typically have their own public affairs units or information officers to ensure that their messages are relayed to the public via the media. For instance, a New York Times article reported that “the Bush administration spent $254 million in its first term on public relations contracts, nearly double what the last Clinton administration spent.”63 Thus, political figures’ use of prepackaged news can be a more covert process that is not as easily recognizable by the public because of the indirect means by which they deliver their messages. The same Times article reported that “at least 20 federal agencies, including the Defense Department and the Census Bureau, have made and distributed hundreds of television news segments” from about 2001 to 2005.64 As found with Farsetta and Price’s study, however, many of these prepackaged news items were broadcast throughout the country without stations acknowledging the government’s production role.65

As with any other successful communication strategy, the government knows to create a specific message and distribute it when it will have the most impact. This was the case when the U.S. government had a VNR created dealing with Medicare. The “interview” with a health and human services secretary was scripted and included a suggested lead-in stating that President Bush had just signed the first prescription drug plan for people using Medicare. Strategically, the report was “distributed in January 2004, not long before Mr. Bush hit the campaign trail and cited the drug benefit as one of his major accomplishments,” according to the New York Times.66

Instead of simply creating and distributing prepackaged news programs, the U.S. government has also garnered favorable discussion of its policies and issues through other means. In approximately one month’s time in 2005, three syndicated conservative columnists were paid thousands of dollars to promote the Bush administration’s agendas.67 Administrations have also reportedly worked their way into primetime programming as far back as the 1980s when Nancy Reagan promoted her “Just Say No” campaign on Diff’rent Strokes and Punky Brewster (Weblink 3).68

sec.title: Organizational Influences
sec.p: In addition to external forces, pressures on the media can also come from people and factors at the organizational level. Influences at the organizational level seem to largely depend on the structure, size, staff, and ownership of the media entity. Economic pressures can also derive from this level of influence and often result from increased bottom-line worries. These economic concerns can constrain work in the media organization and may, in turn, influence decisions about content.69 Constraints and pressures at the organizational level are largely communicated by owners and top executives. Thus, economic and owner/executive pressures and their possible effects on content are first discussed, followed by staff size pressures.

sec.title: Economic Pressures
sec.p: Since many media organizations are publicly traded companies, frontline management and journalists are not only accountable to higher executives, but to stockholders as well. In discussing market-driven journalism, McManus noted that media organizations are a part of a “market-based economy,” and they compete in four different markets: investors, advertisers, sources of news, and consumers.70 He argued that these investors are the most influential in the production of news because they are a part of the corporate structure while the other three markets—advertisers, consumers, and sources—must exert their influence from outside the corporation. Since the investors, or owners, appear to have the strongest influence in media organizations, according to McManus’s model, news workers may feel economic and bottom-line pressures from them or from top-level executives who are likely relaying the messages. Research suggests that they are indeed noticing the effects of these economic concerns in both the newspaper and television industries.

In the newspaper industry, nonindependent entities are often perceived as forcing profit-driven material or as placing profits and financial expectations above journalistic quality.71 At least one study supports the notion that they are only interested in “all the news that makes a profit.”72 This view suggests that corporate executives act as a sieve, allowing only profit-driven news items to seep through. That is, they are serving as gatekeepers controlling the flow of information received by the audience with a motive primarily of financial self-interest.

In 2004, Quill reported that a survey of journalists conducted by four major media-workers unions, including television and newspapers, found that 83 percent of the respondents cited “too much emphasis on the bottom line” as the media industry’s most serious problem.73 The same article referred to a separate survey that found 57 percent of journalists in local newsrooms and 66 percent in national newsrooms felt that “bottom-line pressure is seriously hurting the quality of news coverage.”74

Shoemaker and Reese hypothesized that radio and TV are more sensitive to the need to make a profit than print media because nearly all of their income originates from advertising.75 And “unlike most daily newspapers, television stations compete head to head with comparable organizations offering a very similar product. The inflexible time within which to program commercials translates every programming decision into an economic trade-off.”76 Findings from the Pew Research Center show support for these claims. A 2007 Pew survey found that 65 percent of national and 62 percent of local television journalists believed that bottom-line pressures were seriously hurting the quality of news coverage. These findings represent a 13 (national) and a 16 (local) percentage-point increase from those who were surveyed in 1999 about the same issue.77

sec.title: Owner/Executive Pressures
sec.p: As mentioned, constraints and pressures at the organizational level are largely communicated by top executives and owners. The owners or the head executives, according to Shoemaker and Reese, are the ultimate authority figures in determining the goals and policies of the media organization. Thus, all people working in the organization must answer to them and follow their guidelines if they expect to keep their jobs. They argue that “media owners have an unmistakable impact on media content because they [establish] policy for the entire organization.”78 As media organizations grow larger and become more complex as a result of ownership concentration, top-level executives become more connected to outside organizations. And as McManus points out, “management has a legal responsibility to serve the economic interest of owners.”79 As a result, top-level executives may exert demands on journalists to uphold these economic interests, as well as others. Evidence in literature supports these assertions of executive and owner pressures and influences on content.

Scholars have studied manager and owner pressures regarding profit goals80 and coverage bias81 in the newspaper industry, while other researchers have focused their attention on television. Price examined influences on news content and pressures at the ownership level in her survey of national television news correspondents. She found that approximately 21 percent of those surveyed said that they had felt pressured to report a story because of their owners, while almost the same percentage, 20.6 percent, reported owner pressure not to report a story.82

Pew studies have reported even more instances of owner pressures. A 2000 survey found that 51 percent of local journalists felt that corporate owners influence news organizations’ decisions about which stories to cover or emphasize “a great deal” or “a fair amount.”83 The same question was asked in 2004 and yielded similar results, although responses were also segmented by medium in this survey. Results indicated that 48 percent of local journalists felt the same influence from owners. The responses were comparable within both the print and broadcast industries, but the pressure was especially clear in the latter, as 40 percent of local TV and radio journalists reported “a great deal” or “a fair amount” owner influence on content decisions.84

Gilens and Hertzman examined newspaper coverage of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 in relation to corporate ownership. They found that newspapers that stood to gain from the loosening of television ownership rules, those with television holdings, offered more favorable coverage, while those that were not likely to gain, those without holdings, provided “overwhelmingly unfavorable” coverage of the act.85 Colistra’s86 and Snider and Page’s87 research on news coverage of similar FCC policy issues provided further support for the notion of financial interests of owners influencing content.

Furthermore, Price’s 1998 study of network news coverage of the Telecommunications Act found that only 16 percent of the big three networks’ broadcasts over a three-year period dealt with the act’s potential role in increasing ownership concentration in the television news industry.88 The lack of coverage came as no surprise to one politician. The now-defunct Brill’s Content, a media watchdog magazine, reported that John McCain spoke about the issue in the Senate, claiming, “You will not see this story on any television or hear it on any radio broadcast because it affects them.”89 These findings suggest that media organizations that stand to benefit from policy issues may not necessarily like to bring attention to themselves, while those that do not stand to benefit not only provide more coverage, in most cases, but more negative coverage as well.90

sec.title: Staff Size Pressure
sec.p: The size of a media organization’s staff has been linked to studies regarding ownership,91 competition,92 news quality,93 and overall industry performance,94 to name a few. Although the research focuses on different media and areas, findings typically indicate that a larger staff size is most desirable. For example, Underwood and Stamm examined staff size, among other factors, in their study of newsroom management policies at twelve West Coast newspapers. They found that changes in staff size, which were generally reductions, most often occurred at smaller, family-owned newspapers. During the on-site interviews, the researchers also found that respondents commonly associated a decline in quality with changes in coverage and cutbacks. Thus, a reduction in staff size was viewed as a negative change, while an increase in staff size was viewed positively by the staff members.95

Research also suggests that staff size is related to industry factors other than employee opinions of the issue. In his 1978 study of ownership, CATV, and local television news quality, Busterna found that the control variables for the study—penetration of cable television, household income, UHF/VHF, and number of television stations and households in the market under study—were all related to staff size. Two other main variables in the study, both ownership variables, were not found to affect the size of the news staff.96

In a separate project ten years later, Busterna pointed out that a larger news budget and a larger staff size should generally correspond to the quality of local television news programming.97 The same appeared to be true for newspapers, as Lacy, Fico, and Simon found that industry performance was positively correlated with the size of the news staff.98 Still, the positive implications of a larger staff may not be enough to encourage those in the industry to implement research findings, as evidenced by the subsequent examples.

Bernstein and colleagues’ examination of geographic coverage of local television news found that larger stations devoted a smaller percentage of news space to local news than smaller stations, despite the fact that newscasts were lengthier. The authors proposed that “stations expanding their newscast length do not increase their staff enough to fill the added space with an equivalent amount of local news.”99 In a later study, Powers examined ratings, competition, and conduct in local television news. She found that news programs added more news time per day when they were in intense competition. This competition, however, did not directly affect staff size, which led Powers to argue that “increasing hours of news may initially be seen as a less expensive means of competition than adding staff members.”100

With empirical evidence connecting staff size to performance and quality programming, it seems that media owners and executives would want to increase, or at least maintain, the size of their staffs, despite economic hardships and increased bottom-line pressures that have faced the industry. But how have the number of staffers fared in recent years? According to a 2007 Pew survey, 28 percent of local TV journalists reported that newsroom staff size has decreased over the past three years, while 47 percent said it has stayed the same.101

sec.title: Influences within the Media Organization
sec.p: Along with external forces and broader organizational pressures, influences on media content may also derive from the very place in which it is created: the media organization itself. While Shoemaker and Reese did not specifically name this “within-media organization” level of influence in their onion diagram, they did refer to two other related sources, individual and media routines. As it is conceptualized and explained here, within-media influences incorporate facets from the two aforementioned levels from the hierarchical model. What is different, however, is that the “within-media organization” factor focuses more on forces within the news entity that may affect how journalists produce content and cover (or not cover) certain topics. That is, it centers on possible pressure from management, such as assignment editors or other superiors, working within the news organization.

sec.title: Direct and Indirect Management Pressures
sec.p: Demands from superiors who work in the news organization on a day-to-day basis can be either direct or indirect. Direct pressures are more obvious and may consist of a manager specifically telling a journalist not to cover a story. Or they may provide clear instructions about what topics to cover (or not cover) and how to cover them. A 2000 Pew survey asked print and broadcast journalists about whether journalists sometimes purposely avoid covering certain stories that they believe are truly newsworthy. While 57 percent answered no, 42 percent reported that journalists do sometimes avoid stories.102 Although this figure shows that less than half of the journalists surveyed thought this was a problem, it is large enough to rouse concern. Of those who believed that journalists sometime purposely avoid newsworthy stories, an average of 30 percent (28 percent national and 31 percent local) answered that news workers get signals from their bosses to avoid them. Furthermore, 35 percent (33 percent national and 37 percent local) reported direct signals, such as their superiors’ specifically telling them not to cover it, clear instructions about what types of stories were acceptable/unacceptable, or that it was simply “pretty clear.”103

As Warren Breed noted in the classic study “Social Control in the Newsroom,” management direction is not typically overt or directly stated. Instead, pressure from superiors is usually relayed in a more subtle, indirect manner. As one staffer in the study put it, news routines and policies about what to cover (or not cover) and how to cover it are learned “by osmosis.”104 That is, journalists are socialized over time by methods such as reprimand or editing to learn what types of stories are acceptable. This socialization is also learned through indirect signals, such as “a nod of the head, as if to say, ‘Please don’t rock the boat.’”105 The previously mentioned Pew survey addressed these unspoken, hidden norms and indirect signals. Of those journalists who believed that news workers sometimes purposely avoid newsworthy stories, an average of 24 percent (35 percent national and 17 percent local) said that journalists decide to avoid these stories based on how they believe their bosses would respond.106 This is an example of newsroom routines and socialization within the news organization. Of those 30 percent of journalists who said they avoid stories because they get signals from their superiors, 32 percent claimed that this was a result of “indirect” signals, such as yawning at or poking fun of a story idea, or showing a lack of interest by simply not airing or publishing the story once it is created. If this is repeated over time, journalists learn, or become socialized, to avoid these stories on their own if they want to get rewarded by their superiors. Breed contended that a journalist eventually “learns to anticipate what is expected of him so as to win rewards and avoid punishments.”107

While these hidden norms and routines appear to be powerful in the newsroom culture, they are not afforded as much attention as more direct means of communicating policy. This inattention may be because they are more difficult to define, measure, and analyze. In discussing journalism ethics and codes, newspaperman and media scholar Philip Meyer suggested that, instead of the written formal ethics codes that are found in newsrooms throughout the country, unwritten codes are more often involved in ethical decision making in the newsroom. He explained that these rules become so “deeply embedded in the newsroom culture that they need never be made explicit to be enforced, but can exist simply as a set of reflexes.”108 These “reflexes” are the equivalent of the socialization process in the newsroom to which Breed referred. Perhaps partly because these unspoken codes and “proper” behavior are more difficult to analyze, more direct forms of management communication, such as spoken or written policy, have been more prevalent in scholarship.

sec.title: Influences on Media Content: Different Theoretical Approaches
sec.p: Extramedia, organizational, and within-media forces may attempt to influence news content, and they aim to do so through different means for various reasons. These sources may shape coverage by (1) affecting/influencing the topics, stories, or issues the media actually cover (building the media’s agenda); (2) influencing the way a story, issue, or topic is covered–that is, the angle or tone taken when discussing the topic (building the media’s frames); or (3) convincing the media to give an issue, story, or topic little attention or to not cover it at all (cutting the item from the media’s agenda). For this monograph, special attention is paid to the elucidation of agenda cutting, the third type of influence mentioned, as it is a largely ignored phenomenon that has been afforded little attention by researchers. Thus, this project aims to develop and expand this potentially important area of media scholarship.

sec.title: Agenda Building
sec.p: The mass media’s influence on audiences has been a common area of study ever since the advent of the magic bullet theory in the 1920s and 1930s. Years later, McCombs and Shaw made significant strides in media effects and public opinion research. Their initial agenda-setting study of undecided voters in the 1968 election found that the objects that are emphasized most in the media come to be deemed as most important by the public.109 This led them to cite Cohen’s claim that the press “may not be successful much of the time in telling people what to think, but it is stunningly successful in telling its readers what to think about.”110 Since then, media effects research, particularly agenda setting, has exploded in interest.

While many studies have focused on how media content influences audience cognition, attitudes, and opinion, research concerning how the media are influenced in the first place has been afforded somewhat less attention. Although Rogers, Dearing, and Bregman referred to this process as media agenda setting,111 it is more generally known as agenda building, a term that helps distinguish its application from the media-effects approach of agenda setting. Essentially, while agenda-setting theory suggests that the media tell people “what to think about,” the agenda-building process focuses on the internal and external forces that tell the media what to think (and write) about.

The importance of such research of who or what is building the media’s agenda was noted in the late 1940s by Lazarsfeld and Merton. The authors argued that the media are controlled by powerful businesses and organizations and suggested that these groups set the agenda for the media, and in turn the audience, by influencing the content relayed to the public.112 Cobb and Elder defined agenda building in the political arena as the study “concerned with the identification and specification of the types of issue conflicts that receive the attention and action of governmental decision-makers.”113 In other words, they were “concerned with how issues are created and why some controversies or . . . issues come to command the attention . . . of decision makers, while others fail.”114 Years later, Gandy stressed the role of information subsidies as potential agenda-building mechanisms and sparked a greater interest in this line of scholarship.115 By 1991, Shoemaker and Reese had developed their hierarchical model of influences.116 This “onion diagram” depicts the levels through which media content can be influenced prior to reaching the audience and, thus, has been an essential tool for scholars interested in agenda building. However, while the diagram allows for an easier classification system of where these influences are coming from, it does not provide a comprehensive model that can actually test the pressures and potential effects on the media and news content. Furthermore, as previously noted, few researchers have examined how the media agenda is developed or “set.”117 In fact, in a 1993 article, Rogers, Dearing, and Bregman uncovered only fifteen publications specifically dealing with building the media’s agenda.118 Even though there have been many more studies since then, research in this area still warrants further investigation because, according to the authors, “we need to better understand how the media agenda is set, and by whom.”119

sec.title: Frame Building
sec.p: In addition to building the media’s agenda, external and internal sources may also attempt to control or influence the way a story is covered. That is, they may attempt to frame a story in a light that is more favorable or beneficial to their company, organization, or boss. This process is frame building, and it suggests that internal and external forces tell the media how to think (or write) about an issue, story, or topic. Frames, as Neuman, Just, and Crigler pointed out, involve how the media “spin” the story and should take “into account their organizational and modality constraints, professional judgments, and certain judgments about the audience.”120 According to Maher, framing focuses on environments and relationships. Specifically, framing research not only emphasizes the relationships of frames, words, and sentences within a given text, but it also calls attention to the environments in which they were conceived, such as the source of the frame (e.g., an advertiser) and the intentions of the communicator (e.g., to talk about the positives of a product while downplaying undesirable reviews).121

As some researchers have noted, framing is difficult to study and measure because of vague definitions and the misuse of terms.122 Scheufele has attempted to clarify certain aspects and processes of the approach to aid scholars in this important area of media studies. He has argued that concepts of framing need to be specified “because frames have to be considered schemes for both presenting and comprehending the news.”123 The two types of frames are media frames and audience frames, and it is important for researchers to distinguish between them to determine the best methods and measures for examination in different types of studies. A media frame has been defined by Gamson and Modigliani as “a central organizing idea or story line that provides meaning to an unfolding strip of events. . . . The frame suggests what the controversy is about, the essence of the issue.”124 The conceptualization of media frames can also consist of the inadvertent or deliberate intentions of the internal or external source sending the message.125 The second type of frame, the audience frame, Scheufele notes, is defined by Entman as “mentally stored clusters of ideas that guide an individuals’ processing of information.”126 That is, this type of frame focuses on the individual level of the process. According to Entman, framing not only assigns importance to an issue, but it also presents the issue in such a way as to communicate a certain type of message.127 The media may frame a message in a particular way, based on extramedia, organizational, or within-media sources.

In addition to distinguishing between the types of frames, Scheufele also explained that frames need to be classified by independent and dependent variables.128 When frames are considered independent variables in media research, the study is concerned with framing effects. For example, a researcher might be interested in how frames presented in the media (media frames) influence how the audience understands an issue (audience frame). When the media frame is the dependent variable, the study is concerned with extramedia, organizational, and within-media sources that attempt to influence the way the media frame an issue, topic, or story. Regarding frame building, Scheufele remarked, “No evidence has yet been systematically collected about how various [intrinsic and extrinsic] factors impact the structural qualities of news in terms of framing.”129 Therefore, this somewhat ignored area of scholarship warrants further investigation. This particular classification of framing research is the focus of this monograph.

sec.title: Agenda Cutting
sec.p: While the idea of placing an idea on the news agenda by giving it more salience has been studied for many years, it is interesting that the reverse phenomenon, keeping an item off the agenda, has largely been ignored in scholarly research. This concept is known as agenda cutting.

Although not specifically discussing this phenomenon, McCombs and Shaw alluded to the process in 1984 when explaining that newspaper items are “not treated equally when presented to the audience. Some are used at length, some are severely cut.”130 Still, Wober and Gunter made perhaps the first mention of the term agenda cutting in their 1988 book, Television and Social Control. In relation to agenda setting, they described agenda cutting as a “process whereby problems or issues have attention directed away from them by receiving little or no media coverage.”131 Thus, it is proposed that agenda cutting may occur in three ways: (1) by placing an item low on the news agenda (burying it), (2) by removing it from agenda once it is there, or (3) by completely ignoring it by never placing it on the agenda in the first place.

The process of agenda cutting has been mentioned by few scholars and researched by even fewer, which, according to Wober, is largely due to its lack of identification and documentation.132 He provided a notable American example that took place in 1864 when General Meade humiliated a news reporter. In return, the northern press apparently ignored (cut) all stories about Meade except those associated with defeat. Surely stories about the general were deemed newsworthy by the press. But because of his harsh action against the reporter, they cut complimentary stories about him out of the public’s attention. As a result, Wober suggested, Meade was reduced to a “non-person.”133

Project Censored, a media group based out of Sonoma State University, has investigated instances of “news stories of social significance” that did not run in the mainstream media.134 Each year, the organization compiles a list of twenty-five stories obtained from independent news sources that were ignored, for the most part, by national media. Although the Project does not explicitly examine possible reasons why these items were cut or the effects on audience cognition, it does provide useful examples on which to base agenda-cutting scholarship.

Media Tenor has been perhaps the only organization specifically researching the area of agenda cutting. The international institute specializes in detailed and continuous content analysis of the media, mainly examining agenda setting.135 In 2003, Media Tenor published a study examining the agenda-setting and agenda-cutting effects of German television news coverage of mad cow disease from 1997 to 2002. The first official case of the disease was announced in late 2000 and received substantial television coverage. During this time, the broadcast media appeared to set the agenda, as 73 percent of respondents in an unaffiliated opinion poll “felt threatened” by the disease, while 58 percent altered their consumption of beef.136 The extensive coverage also coincided with a sharp dip in German beef consumption figures.

According to the study, the media had substantially decreased the amount of mad-cow coverage by 2001, which coincided with a 26 percentage-point decrease in the number of polled German respondents feeling endangered by the disease. By 2002, however, television coverage was placed so low on the news agenda that it was almost nonexistent. To test the cutting effects, Media Tenor correlated the scant television coverage with German beef consumption. The organization found that a decrease in news about the disease correlated with a slow increase in consumption, despite the fact there were nearly as many confirmed cases (106) as when the first official case was confirmed in 2001 (125).137 As this example illustrates, cutting an important item from the news agenda may lead to an uninformed public.

Although Wober began mentioning agenda cutting in the late 1980s, he did not discuss it in much detail until 2001. While he did not actually test the phenomenon, he did provide several examples that suggested agenda cutting does exist. More importantly, he proposed three main reasons why agenda cutting may occur, which essentially deal with logistical constraints, journalists’ own prejudices, and internal and external influences.138

sec.title: Logistical constraints
sec.p: Agenda cutting may occur because of logistical constraints, such as the size of the news hole and reporting staff. First, news organizations can only report on a certain number of topics at a time, which results in the elimination of others. Selecting topics, however, may not be a deliberate process. In discussing agenda setting, McCombs argued that the selection of objects usually occurs fortuitously, at least for media in democratic cultures. He explained that “because agenda-setting is an inadvertent outcome of reporting the news, this is a role that cannot be abdicated or sidestepped.”139 The same is likely true for agenda cutting.

sec.title: Journalists’ prejudices
sec.p: Wober claimed that agenda cutting may also occur because of prejudices of journalists and news organizations. This reasoning falls in line with White’s 1950 gatekeeping study in which he suggested that “Mr. Gates” used subjective judgment, including his own personal prejudices, when deciding what stories to omit.140 It is important to note, however, that this type of cutting by journalists may be unintentional.

sec.title: Internal and external influences
sec.p: Finally, agenda cutting may occur when people within or outside the news organization “do their best to hide or camouflage stories.”141 This possible reason is the focus of this monograph. Wober gave an example of an internal e-mail that was circulated by an executive for the British Transport Ministry immediately following the 9/11 New York terrorist attacks. The message read, “It’s now a very good day to get out anything we want to bury. Councillors’ expenses?”142 The story was leaked to the press nearly a month later, when it was confirmed that the department in question had, in fact, released the unfavorable information on September 12.

Although not specifically examining agenda cutting, separate studies by Snider and Page,143 Price,144 and others145 have shown some evidence that organizational-level sources have cut issues from the media agenda by affording topics little attention or failing to cover them at all. For example, in her 1998 study of network news coverage of the Telecommunications Act of 1996, Price found that only 16 percent of the big three networks’ broadcasts over a three-year period dealt with the act’s potential role in increasing ownership concentration in the television news industry.146 Colistra’s pilot study, which specifically examined a policy issue through the agenda-cutting lens, provides additional support.147 This research investigated the FCC’s digital spectrum “loan” to broadcasters examined coverage from the three major networks, CNN, and two national newspapers. Colistra found strong evidence for her agenda-cutting hypothesis, as the media entities that stood to gain from the giveaway, the network television stations, ignored the issue over the nine-year period of study, while the newspapers placed it low on their agendas and CNN only ran one relevant broadcast. She also found that when the newspapers covered the issue, more than 44 percent of their hard news coverage was either “negative” or “very negative,” compared to only 4 percent of “positive” coverage. These findings suggest that media organizations that stand to benefit from policy issues may not necessarily like to bring attention to themselves, while those that do not stand to benefit may not only provide more coverage but more negative coverage as well. The two examples illustrate how forces from the organizational level or within the media (e.g., owners/executives or managers who make editorial decisions) and external sources (e.g., government legislation involving the media) may lead to instances of agenda cutting.

In short, agenda cutting may occur by (1) placing an item low on the news agenda, (2) removing it from the agenda once it is there, or (3) completely ignoring it by never putting it on the agenda in the first place. Because the concept of agenda cutting has been examined by few researchers, this monograph attempts to further develop and expand the approach. As mentioned, one aspect of the current research specifically focuses on how often and under what conditions agenda cutting is most like to occur. As with the other potential influences on content just discussed, attention is concentrated on internal and external sources that may help cause this phenomenon. By beginning with the potential causes of agenda cutting, scholars will be better able to understand this approach and begin to form research questions regarding motives behind “cutting” certain topics, stories, and issues from the media agenda; its effects on news coverage; and its possible outcomes on audience cognition.

sec.title: Study Justification
sec.p: While numerous studies have focused on how the media set the audience agenda, fewer have taken a step back to get to the root of matter: how the media’s agenda is influenced in the first place. Although some research has examined these different forces and their potential effects separately (e.g., public relations or advertising pressures effects on building the media’s agenda or frames), no known research has studied how various influences may simultaneously affect news coverage or content decisions. Likewise, little research has concentrated on the much-ignored, but important, phenomenon of agenda cutting. Although Wober coined the term and established the baseline knowledge for this type of research, there have been no known comprehensive efforts to further develop, explain, or test this concept. Each of the previously mentioned areas needs to be explored to determine how internal and external forces attempt to affect news content and coverage decisions. This type of research is especially pertinent in the current media landscape where news workers are faced with multiple competing loyalties, which are at least partially due to increased economic constraints and bottom-line pressures.

sec.title: Hypothesized Model
sec.p: Using aspects from Shoemaker and Reese’s hierarchical model of influences, along with research and examples from agenda-building and framing literature and media surveys, a comprehensive model of media influences and outcomes was tested using structural equation modeling and a national web survey of television reporters (see Figure 2). This analysis examined the overall picture and assessed possible pressures on media content decisions and potential outcomes of these influences, based on reporters’ perceptions. Specifically, the overall model evaluated within-media organization influences as mediating the relationships between extramedia and organizational influences and the proposed content outcomes. This systematic and comprehensive approach helps to improve our understanding of the different types of pressures media organizations face every day. This model also helps to advance our knowledge of agenda building, frame building, and agenda cutting in the news industry.
